comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: A Miss Effie Loader, graduate of the University of Kansas, was a parole officer in Kansas in the 1910s, connected to the Girls' Industrial School at Beloit. That might explain her star-shaped badge in this portrait. In the 1930s she shows up as Superintendent of the State Orphans' Home in Atchison. She's also mentioned in this article as a founder of the Clay Center Carnegie Library in Kansas. claycenter.mykansaslibrary.org/?page_id=26

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: "The Kansas Senate today has a woman Sergeant-at-Arms for the first time in its history. She Is Miss Effie Loader.  Lieutenant Governor W. Y. (William Yoast) Morgan appointed her In recognition of his women constituents." — The Washington [DC] Herald,  January 17, 1915.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Oh cool, I was thinking she must have done something more than run a Kansas reform school to make the Bain Service.  Thanks!

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: I 'dunno if there's any real difference between running a reform school and trying to keep order in a state legislature.  Maybe the hooligans are older in one than in the other.
